forecast.rationale:
Baseline: Cross-border kinetic strikes by India into Pakistan proper are rare. In the past decade, the notable precedent is the 2019 Balakot airstrike in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa following the Pulwama attack; 2016 “surgical strikes” were in Pakistan-administered Kashmir (not among the listed provinces). Routine ceasefire violations are mostly along the LoC and typically confined to Kashmir sectors, which would not satisfy this question’s geographic criteria. There has been a general de-escalation since the 2021 ceasefire understanding.
Time window: The window is only June 2025, which further lowers odds. Even if tensions exist, aligning a triggering event, decision, preparation, and execution all within a single month is unlikely absent strong, visible precursors.
Drivers toward Yes: A mass-casualty attack in India with a clear link to Pakistan-based groups; strong domestic pressure for retaliation; visible military preparations (IAF forward deployments, NOTAMs, airspace restrictions, unusual troop movements), and escalatory official rhetoric. The precedent of Balakot shows India is willing to strike in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa under certain conditions.
Drivers toward No: Nuclear deterrence and escalation risks; international diplomatic pressure; India’s preference for limited, deniable, or non-kinetic responses; and the enduring 2021 ceasefire. Without a major provocation, New Delhi has little incentive to cross the international border into Pakistan’s provinces.
Why not higher: There is no known trigger as of May 22, 2025, the window is narrow, and the costs/risks of escalation are substantial. These factors keep the probability well below 10%.
Why not lower: Precedent exists (2019), and unforeseen provocations can arise quickly. India maintains capabilities for limited punitive action, including stand-off strikes or drones, that could be executed rapidly if a trigger occurs.
Signals to update upward: Credible reports of a mass-casualty attack in India attributed to Pakistan-based groups; explicit retaliatory rhetoric by top Indian leadership; visible IAF/Army mobilization, NOTAMs, cross-border airspace closures, or evacuation orders for border communities; Pakistani alerts or defensive mobilization.
Signals to update downward: Continued quiet along the IB/LoC through mid-June; conciliatory diplomatic signaling; absence of militant incidents; reaffirmations of the ceasefire.
